a second integer

name: CochainComplex.HomComplex.Triplet.q

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the remainder when `n` is divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. This is equivalent to saying that any natural number is either even (divisible by 2) or odd (leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 2).

name: Nat.mod_two_eq_zero_or_one
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the remainder when `n` is divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. This is equivalent to saying that any natural number is either even (divisible by 2) or odd (leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 2).

a first integer

name: CochainComplex.HomComplex.Triplet.p
docString: a first integer

A natural number is even if and only if it is not odd. Equivalently, a natural number is even if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number, and it is odd if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number plus 1.

name: Nat.even_iff_not_odd
docString: A natural number is even if and only if it is not odd. Equivalently, a natural number is even if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number, and it is odd if and only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number plus 1.

The theorem `Nat.prime_two` asserts that the number 2 is a prime number. In the context of natural numbers, a prime number is defined as a natural number greater than or equal to 2 whose only divisors are itself and 1. Therefore, this theorem is confirming that 2, which is divisible only by itself and 1, satisfies this property and is therefore a prime number.

name: Nat.prime_two
docString: The theorem `Nat.prime_two` asserts that the number 2 is a prime number. In the context of natural numbers, a prime number is defined as a natural number greater than or equal to 2 whose only divisors are itself and 1. Therefore, this theorem is confirming that 2, which is divisible only by itself and 1, satisfies this property and is therefore a prime number.

The digits in the base b+2 expansion of n are all less than b+2

type: ∀ {b m d : ℕ}, d ∈ Nat.digits (b + 2) m → d < b + 2
name: Nat.digits_lt_base'
docString: The digits in the base b+2 expansion of n are all less than b+2

an n-digit number in base b + 2 is less than (b + 2)^n

type: ∀ {b : ℕ} {l : List ℕ}, (∀ x ∈ l, x < b + 2) → Nat.ofDigits (b + 2) l < (b + 2) ^ List.length l
name: Nat.ofDigits_lt_base_pow_length'
docString: an n-digit number in base b + 2 is less than (b + 2)^n

The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.

type: ∀ {a b x y u v : ℕ}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 → b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 → ∃ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2
